page_content.content_body: Approve the 2025 Asset Management Plans as attached in Documents 1 – 12 and as described in this report. Direct staff return to Committee and Council in 2028 with updated Asset Management Plans and continue to report every four years hereafter. Approve an update to the City of Ottawa’s Asset Management Policy as attached in Document 13 and as described in this report. Direct staff to update the asset management program and governance structure. Direct staff to include a mandatory asset management implications section in Committee and Council reports as a part of the consultations for the 2026-2030 Term of Council Governance Review.

The 2025 Asset Management Plans (AMPs) mark a significant milestone for Ottawa, representing the first time comprehensive and standardized data on all municipal assets, worth approximately $90 billion, have been consolidated into a single, unified framework. The AMPs offer a clear view of the current state of Ottawa’s infrastructure: it is safe, in good to fair condition, and continues to serve residents. The 2025 AMPs fulfill the final phase of Ontario Regulation 588/17, building on the 2022 and 2024 Council-approved AMPs highlighting all asset classes across all City services, including roads, water and wastewater systems, transit, recreation, libraries, emergency services, and more.

page_content.context_header: All Asset Classes Across City Services
page_content.content_body: The 2025 AMPs highlight all asset classes across all City services, including roads, water and wastewater systems, transit, recreation, libraries, emergency services, and more.

Each AMP presents a consistent summary of: The inventory and condition of City-owned assets. Service levels currently delivered and Council-approved targets for the next 10 years. Forecasted lifecycle costs for renewal, growth, and climate change adaptation.

Over the next 10 years, a $10.8 billion gap is forecasted between projected infrastructure needs and planned funding. This gap reflects asset renewal, growth, service enhancements, and climate change adaptation and mitigation costs.

The 2025 Asset Management Plans are not a request for new capital funding; they are a strategic tool to help Council and staff understand the current state of infrastructure, forecast future needs, and make informed decisions that balance cost, risk, and service delivery.

The financial analysis supporting the AMPs is based on the City’s 2024 financial strategy. Future AMPs will incorporate new funding strategies, such as the Long Range Financial Plans (LRFPs), as they are approved by Council. Upcoming updates to rate-supported and tax-supported LRFPs will serve as the key vehicle for identifying funding strategies to respond to priority funding requirements within affordable parameters.

The City uses a risk-based approach to prioritize investments, focusing on safety, criticality, and service continuity. The 2025 AMPs offer the opportunity to highlight non-financial strategies to optimize asset use, adjust service levels and explore innovative delivery models.

The 2025 AMPs are aligned with the City’s Long-Range Financial Plans and other strategic documents, including the Climate Change Master Plan and Infrastructure Master Plan. Together, these plans provide a coordinated framework for managing infrastructure in a way that is sustainable, resilient, and responsive to community needs.

The City of Ottawa’s asset management journey began in 2001 with the amalgamation of several municipalities into one unified city, consolidating diverse inventories, service standards, and operational approaches. Since then, Ottawa has progressively developed a structured approach to asset management, leading to the launch of the Comprehensive Asset Management Program in 2012.

In 2001, the amalgamated City of Ottawa brought together a diverse inventory of assets, service standards, and operational approaches, laying the groundwork for a cohesive understanding of its asset base.
Between 2002 and 2003, the City introduced its first structured Long-Range Financial Plans (LRFPs), providing a framework for financial planning tied to asset priorities.

page_content.context_header: 2004-2007 Capital Standards Review and Third LRF
page_content.content_body: From 2004 to 2007, Ottawa advanced its approach through a Capital Standards Review (ACS2004-TUP-INF-0009) and the development of a third Long-Range Financial Plan, strengthening investment standards and planning processes.

In 2012, the City launched the Comprehensive Asset Management Program (ACS2012-PAI-INF-0007), establishing new structure, stability, and consistency in managing infrastructure, including the Program and State of the Asset report, Comprehensive Asset Management Policy, Strategy, and Canadian Infrastructure Report Card.
The report recommends updating the Asset Management Policy (Document 13) and implementing governance and training enhancements to strengthen asset management practices organization-wide.
The AMPs promote transparency and public engagement by clearly communicating challenges and opportunities related to Ottawa’s infrastructure, fostering informed public discourse.

The 2025 AMPs align with the City’s Long-Range Financial Plans, Climate Change Master Plan, and Infrastructure Master Plan, providing a coordinated framework for sustainable, resilient infrastructure management.
The City will continue to report annually on asset management progress as required by Ontario Regulation 588/17.
The report recommends that staff return to Council in 2028 with updated Asset Management Plans to ensure continuous improvement and alignment with evolving priorities.

In 2017, the Comprehensive Asset Management Program was updated (ACS2017-PIE-IS-0002) along with the State of the Asset Report and Strategic Asset Management Plan. The update complemented the tax and rate Long Range Financial Plan V for tax-supported capital and the water, wastewater, and stormwater rate-supported capital (ACS2017-CSD-FIN-0017 and ACS2017-CSD-FIN-0023).

In 2018, the Province introduced the Asset Management Planning for Municipal Infrastructure Regulation, O. Reg. 588/17 (as amended by O. Reg. 193/21), strengthening municipal asset management practices, standardizing plans, and requiring consistent reporting.

The regulation requires: 1) Approval of drinking water, wastewater, stormwater and transportation AMPs by July 1, 2022; 2) Approval of all remaining AMPs by July 1, 2024; 3) Approval of all AMPs updated to include target level of service, funding and risk mitigation by July 1, 2025; 4) Annual review on or before July 1 each year starting the year after the plan is completed; 5) Update of AMPs to reflect present conditions at least every five years after completion.

page_content.context_header: 2022 Water, Wastewater, Stormwater & Transportation AMPs Approval
page_content.content_body: On April 13, 2022, City Council approved ACS2022-IWS-AM-0001, the drinking water, wastewater, stormwater and transportation Asset Management Plans, covering over 80% of Ottawa's owned asset value.
On May 15, 2024, City Council approved ACS2024-IWS-AM-0002, the remaining AMPs, covering the other 20% of Ottawa's owned asset value.
Municipal asset management progress must be reviewed annually on or before July 1, starting the year after the asset management plan is completed, as required by O. Reg. 588/17.
Asset management plans must be updated to reflect present conditions at least every five years after completion, per O. Reg. 588/17.

The 2025 Asset Management Plans complete the third phase of the regulatory requirements by adding target levels of service, funding plan, and risks to service where forecasted service needs exceed planned funding. The AMPs are grouped by eight service areas and include information on buildings, fleet and special equipment assets that support these services.
On May 13, 2025, the Ottawa Public Library Board approved the Library Asset Management Plan, which is included in the 2025 AMP package for Committee and Council approval.

The 2025 AMPs serve as a strategic tool connecting asset data, service levels, risk management, and long-term financial planning. They are not a request for capital investment, nor do they propose changes to level of service or funding. Instead, they provide an overview of asset condition, service level performance, anticipated lifecycle needs, and associated risks over the coming decade, bridging technical asset information with service delivery expectations to support informed investment decisions.

The 2025 AMPs serve as a strategic tool connecting asset data, service levels, risk management, and long-term financial planning. They provide an overview of asset condition, service level performance, anticipated lifecycle needs, and associated risks over the coming decade, bridging technical asset information with service delivery expectations to support informed investment decisions.

The AMPs act as a communications tool to support productive dialogue with the community about balancing service expectations, affordability, and risk of service disruption, and to share information on current conditions, service levels, projected funding versus forecasted need, and anticipated future risks.
This report seeks Council’s approval of the 12 Service Area AMPs (Documents 1–12) as required under Ontario Regulation 588/17.

Over the next 10 years, external drivers will increase challenges to operation, renewal, maintenance, acquisition and divestment of municipal assets. Key considerations include historic asset age, regulatory changes, accessibility, equity, inflationary pressures, and climate change.
Much of Ottawa’s infrastructure was built post-war with varied standards and funding models, requiring continued investment to maintain and renew assets to remain safe and functional.
Incremental regulatory and policy changes, including Ontario Regulation 588/17, increase financial pressures to modify or enhance existing municipal assets rather than simply renew them.
Modern standards around accessibility, equity, diversity, and inclusion require increased investments to enhance assets to support current service delivery.
Current asset replacement values are rising due to inflationary pressures, supply chain issues, material and labour shortages, leading to higher forecasted renewal and enhancement costs.
Climate change necessitates earlier asset replacement due to premature deterioration, mitigation of future impacts, reduction of GHG emissions, and recovery from extreme weather events.

The 2025 AMPs provide a baseline to measure progress, prioritize investments, and support evidence-informed decision-making to maintain service stability as infrastructure ages, costs rise, and community expectations evolve.

The 2025 AMPs show that City-owned assets on average are in good to fair condition. The City’s assets are safe and support their respective services with no immediate service risk across the 12 service areas.

The service area gaps are a snapshot of 2024, reflecting past decisions on service level expectations and City investment patterns. The gaps represent the total needs if all projects were implemented today, not a prioritized list. They are based on the City’s 2024 financial strategy and will incorporate future funding strategies such as Long Range Financial Plans (LRFPs).

Growth (or expansion) refers to activities that introduce entirely new assets or expand the capacity of existing ones to accommodate the city’s development. Sources include development charges background studies, development plans, master plans, Infrastructure Master Plan, Water Purification Plant Comprehensive Development Plan, Wastewater Collection System and Pumping Station Master Plan, Design Guidelines, MECP permits and licenses, DWQMS risk assessments, theoretical capacity analyses, functional designs, project bundling requirements, and business case reviews.

Enhancement (or upgrade) refers to modifying and improving existing assets to meet higher service levels, such as backup power supply, improved operational controls, public safety and security upgrades, new policy objectives, or regulatory compliance (e.g., Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act). Sources include accessibility audits, building condition assessments, service delivery leads input, watermain extensions for system looping, fire flow improvements, and targeted facility upgrades.

Renewal involves rehabilitation of existing assets to restore original quality, capacity, or functionality, ensuring continued service. Includes like-for-like replacement and capital investment activities such as planning, condition assessment, inspections, and opportunistic renewal works. Calculations use building condition audits and lifecycle models reviewed by engineering staff for assets like bridges and culverts.

The total calculated service area gap for 12 AMPs over the next 10 years is $10.8 billion. This reflects projected needs for growth, renewal, and enhancement at target service levels, including climate change impacts. The forecast is based on a 10-year extrapolation of the 2024 annual capital budget to 2034 and incorporates data from previous AMPs, development charge studies, master plans, Climate Change Master Plan, Transit LRP, and Solid Waste LRP.

metadata.topic: Expected and Target Level of Service

page_content.context_header: Expected and Target Level of Service
page_content.content_body: The AMPs establish three service level measures: Current (existing data), Expected (projected under current funding), and Target (policy/strategy based, regardless of budget). Current and target legislated service levels are met; high-risk services are prioritized; lower scores don’t always mean worse user experience; investment needs differ by service; some gaps stem from low-risk, still-functional assets.

Risks include underfunding across renewal, growth, and enhancement needs, leading to elevated long-term costs, deferred investment, and service reliability changes. Additional risks: inflationary pressures, delayed climate mitigation implementation, extended enhancement policy implementation, reliance on staff contingency plans. Mitigation uses a risk-based asset management framework aligned with Enterprise Risk Management, prioritizing investments based on condition, service impact, criticality, safety, and affordability.

Transportation, drinking water, wastewater, and stormwater asset portfolios have updated renewal estimates reflecting higher replacement costs driven by construction inflation, supply chain pressures, and integration of climate change adaptation and resilience investments based on updated modelling.

Service area gaps are based on the 2024 financial strategy and will incorporate future funding strategies such as Long Range Financial Plans (LRFPs) once approved by Council, ensuring alignment with fiscal planning.

Coordinated maintenance, capital planning, and long-term financial strategies; regular updates to master plans, Development Charges By-law, and Climate Change Master Plan; prioritization frameworks to identify highest risk assets, essential services, adapt to changing needs, and incorporate public input.

Assets prioritized based on likelihood of failure and potential consequences if failure occurs; technical inputs include asset condition assessment, regulatory codes, industry practices, criticality or high occupant loads, mission-critical functions, and other asset-specific factors. Asset-level data support safety assessment and system impact analysis.

Even with proactive investment, some infrastructure risks cannot be fully eliminated. Residual risk refers to the remaining level of service or asset risk of failure after planned investments, which is managed within practical tolerances.

Municipal services and supporting assets are on the front lines of climate change. Asset management must adapt to mitigate contribution to climate change and respond to accelerated deterioration, increased operational costs, more frequent maintenance, renewal schedules, and changes in service level expectations, such as disaster planning and contingency funding.

The 2025 AMPs forecast capital and operating costs related to climate change, including increased operations and maintenance costs and capital renewal costs for buildings based on the Financial Accountability Office of Ontario’s Costing Climate Change Impacts to Public Infrastructure (CIPI) Report. Ottawa-specific data and municipality-wide data inform these projections.

The total calculated service area gap for 12 AMPs over the next 10 years is $10.8 billion. This reflects projected needs for growth, renewal, and enhancement at target service levels, including climate change impacts. The forecast is based on a 10-year extrapolation of the 2024 annual capital budget to 2034 and incorporates data from previous AMPs, development charge studies, master plans, Climate Change Master Plan, Transit LRP, and Solid Waste LRP.

Ottawa’s approach to infrastructure planning is supported by strong alignment between Asset Management Plans (AMPs) and Long-Range Financial Plans (LRFPs). The AMPs provide input into the updated Rate LRFP and Tax LRFP, helping develop a ten-year funding strategy that addresses essential needs where risk cannot be mitigated without investment.

page_content.content_body: Inclusion of AMPs training in the 2026 Term of Council councillor orientation to enhance understanding of asset management principles, legislative requirements, policy, and decision-making roles.

Proposed framework to modernize municipal revenue, address a projected $52B infrastructure investment shortfall over the next decade, and provide sustainable, predictable, and equitable funding tools aligned with 21st-century growth demands.

Ontario municipalities face a $52B infrastructure investment shortfall over the next decade, with $21B required for roads and an additional $5.3B annually until at least 2030 for climate mitigation and adaptation.

Municipal revenue framework is outdated and cannot meet modern infrastructure demands; reform is necessary to avoid deferring critical projects, hinder housing and economic development, and ensure delivery of essential services.

No financial implications to this report. Council approved Long Range Financial Plan for Tax Supported Capital and Transit remain in effect. LRFP for Rate will be presented to Committee and Council alongside 2025 Asset Management Plans. Transit and Tax LRFP will be updated in Q3 2025.
No legal impediments to adopting the recommendations. Adoption allows City to meet continuing legal obligations under Ontario Regulation 588/17 and Infrastructure for Jobs and Prosperity Act, 2015.
This is a citywide report.

No public consultations associated with this report as it is administrative in nature. The 12 AMPs were developed through collaboration of over 100 staff, 40 directors, all General Managers, and service-specific teams.

Consulting with the public and the Accessibility Advisory Committee per Integrated Accessibility Standards Regulation 191/11 and Accessibility with Ontarians with Disabilities Act, 2005. Includes Provincial Design of Public Spaces Standard, Ontario Building Code, Canadian Standards Association requirements to ensure accessibility of City facilities and infrastructure.

Implementation of asset management principles leads to timely decisions that minimize lifecycle costs and support long-term affordability of service delivery. Supports compliance with mandatory provincial regulation and eligibility for provincial and federal funding.

Ontario Regulation 588/17 requires climate change considerations in AMPs. Climate change needs were compared with 2024 10-year capital budget forecast; 2025 budget forecast allocated $155M less than 2024 budget over 10 years, indicating a shift in trends.

The report includes a summary of climate change considerations, comparing climate change needs with the 2024 10-year capital budget forecast. The 2025 budget forecast allocated $155 million less than the 2024 budget over 10 years, indicating a shift in trends.
Risk management implications are contained in the report. The City’s asset management planning uses a risk-based approach in decision-making for infrastructure assets.
Asset management planning provides a holistic approach to managing the City’s infrastructure, including services delivered to rural residents and businesses.

The report supports the 2023-2026 Term of Council Priorities: 1) Affordable housing and livable city; 2) Connected, reliable, safe and accessible mobility; 3) Green and resilient city; 4) Diversified and prosperous economy.
